title: 109_hr3492
content: The "Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005" prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. The "Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005" prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts. SEC. 3. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and percentage of the outstanding balance, along with the estimated number of months to pay off the balance if only minimum payments are made. The creditor must apply the applicable annual percentage rate of interest in effect on the date of disclosure, considering different rates for various outstanding balance portions, to determine the total outstanding balance if the consumer pays only the required minimum monthly payments and refrains from further advances or credit extensions. The creditor must consider the annual percentage rate of interest in effect on the disclosure date, including different rates for various outstanding balance portions. If the rate is temporary or introductory, it will change based on an index or formula for subsequent adjustments. The creditor must apply the annual percentage rate of interest in effect on the disclosure date for the introductory or temporary period, and an interest rate based on an index or formula for the remaining amortization period. SEC. 4. ADVANCED NOTICE REQUIRED BEFORE INCREASING RATES OR FEES ON CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts, ensuring that changes do not take effect before the beginning of the billing cycle that starts at least 30 days after the obligor receives a specific notice. The Truth in Lending Act now requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. Changes cannot take effect before the beginning of the billing cycle that starts at least 30 days after the obligor receives a specific notice. Additionally, no fees, including annual fees, late payment fees, or over-the-limit fees, can be imposed on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan. The Truth in Lending Act requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. No fees can be imposed on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan before the end of a 30-day notice period. The notice must be sent separately from any statement or other notice, and must include an explanation of how, when, and why a fee will be imposed. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of fee increases on credit card accounts, with fees not allowed before a 30-day notice period. The notice must be sent separately, explaining the fee imposition process.
